topics.title: Test-everything mindset and expected failure rates
topics.summary: Ronny argues every code/feature change should be experimented on, emphasizing that even small fixes can have unexpected impacts. He sets expectations that most ideas—especially big bets—will fail, so teams must be psychologically and operationally ready for frequent null/negative results.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the show and Ronny’s background across Airbnb, Microsoft, and Amazon, plus what the episode will cover (validity, trust, p-values, culture, and getting started).

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Mixpanel and Round.

topics.title: Surprising wins: tiny UI change, huge revenue
topics.summary: Ronny shares Bing’s famous experiment moving an ad line, which unexpectedly increased revenue ~12% without hurting guardrails, illustrating why intuition is unreliable. They discuss follow-on experiments to understand the causal drivers and how small changes can produce outsized gains.

topics.title: How often big wins happen and why most fail
topics.summary: Ronny explains that most progress is incremental (many small lifts compounding), citing Bing and Airbnb examples. He shares typical failure rates (66% to 92% by context) and clarifies that experiment-level failure includes aborted runs and iterations, not just “bad ideas.”

topics.title: Reusable patterns and institutional learning systems
topics.summary: They discuss collecting “what works” patterns (papers like Rules of Thumb and resources like goodui.org) and the importance of institutional memory. Ronny recommends searchable experiment archives and quarterly reviews of the most surprising wins/losses to drive learning and culture.

topics.title: Can experimentation hinder innovation? Portfolio approach
topics.summary: Ronny argues you can’t experiment too much, but you can over-focus on incrementalism; teams should run a portfolio of low-risk iterations plus high-risk, high-reward bets. He gives Bing’s social integration effort as an example of a large bet that failed despite heavy investment and many experiments.

topics.title: When not to A/B test and when to start
topics.summary: Ronny notes some domains aren’t testable (e.g., M&A) and that small companies may lack sufficient sample sizes. He gives practical thresholds: tens of thousands of users to start (only detect big effects), and ~200k users where experimentation becomes much more powerful.

topics.title: OEC: optimizing for long-term user value
topics.summary: Ronny explains the Overall Evaluation Criterion (OEC) as a way to avoid short-term revenue hacks by incorporating guardrails and long-term value proxies. Examples include ad load constraints in search and using predicted post-stay satisfaction/ratings in travel marketplaces.

topics.title: Measuring long-term effects: holdouts and models
topics.summary: They cover approaches to long-term impact: running longer experiments for learning and building models that price in downstream costs. Ronny’s Amazon email example shows how adding unsubscribe cost revealed many campaigns were net-negative and led to better unsubscribe UX and healthier incentives.

topics.title: Why big redesigns fail and how to de-risk
topics.summary: Ronny and Lenny discuss how full redesigns often test negative and create sunk-cost pressure to ship anyway. Ronny recommends decomposing changes (OFAT or small bundles), testing iteratively, and not shipping flat results due to maintenance costs—except for true constraints like legal requirements.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Eppo, an A/B testing platform.

topics.title: Airbnb experimentation culture and Covid-era decisions
topics.summary: Ronny shares limited observations: his Airbnb search relevance org tested everything, while other areas varied; he argues more experimentation likely would have improved outcomes, though the counterfactual is unknowable. He also contends crises like Covid make experimentation more—not less—important, citing examples like online experiences as a bet with weak data.

topics.title: Writing the book and its reception
topics.summary: Ronny begins reflecting on writing Trustworthy Online Controlled Experiments, noting he was surprised by how well it sold relative to publisher expectations and how niche he initially thought the topic was.
